headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, things obviously are moving around as we hear from policymakers in Washington around the capital rules. As of now, there's no draft capital rules out to -- for us to look at and consider with respect to our business. So while we thought these rules w
componenttext: Tom, things obviously are moving around as we hear from policymakers in Washington around the capital rules. As of now, there's no draft capital rules out to -- for us to look at and consider with respect to our business. So while we thought these rules will be out well before now, we're still waiting. And our decision a couple of years back was to begin returning capital to shareholders excess free cash flow, and we built up what we believe is a good buffer. But again, it's uncertain, and we don't know how this will all play out. So it -- right now, it's a little bit of a judgment call. And we are, in this year, looking to return to shareholders the free cash flow that the business generated. I think if nothing changes in the external world, that would be the pace we'd be on going forward in 2016 as well. But I have to put some caveats in here because there could be a change in the environment that we learn about at some point in the future, but that is our current thinking.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the 50%, if nothing else changed, let's say, it continue to be delayed for whatever reason, you'd be comfortable with the 50% based on what you know today?
componenttext: Okay. So the 50%, if nothing else changed, let's say, it continue to be delayed for whatever reason, you'd be comfortable with the 50% based on what you know today?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: We'd be comfortable with what we're generating in terms of free cash flow. And we are targeting at the 45% to 55% levels. So assuming we achieve that, that would be a fairly good number to think about. And if draft rules come out next year, that could impact our thinking, of course.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then -- and the changes or the charges that you had this quarter related to both the tax item as well as the change in RBC coming from some adjustments to the variable -- the onshoring of the variable annuity business, so the impact from that, would that affect the way you're thinking about returning capital and cash flow or no?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is John. These -- our guidance of the 45% to 55% is still within these -- the RBC and the tax charges that we've already spoken about.
componenttext: This is John. These -- our guidance of the 45% to 55% is still within these -- the RBC and the tax charges that we've already spoken about.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one last one if I could sneak it in. The cash flow project, can you comment on what should we be thinking related to this? I mean, I presume the goal is to move it higher. But are we talking about -- from the 45% to 55%, are we talking abou
componenttext: Okay. And then one last one if I could sneak it in. The cash flow project, can you comment on what should we be thinking related to this? I mean, I presume the goal is to move it higher. But are we talking about -- from the 45% to 55%, are we talking about potentially moving it meaningfully? Or do you think it's going to be very marginal in terms of where this might go?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, we're in the process of finalizing our analysis on this, so it's too early to say how that number would be impacted. But the goal clearly is to raise the number, and we're looking at all of our businesses by product, by geography, by customer. There'
componenttext: Tom, we're in the process of finalizing our analysis on this, so it's too early to say how that number would be impacted. But the goal clearly is to raise the number, and we're looking at all of our businesses by product, by geography, by customer. There's a great deal of very granular analysis that's ongoing. And we're looking at a number of factors as we think of our businesses, including quicker paybacks on our products. So the goal here is to improve free cash flow. And I should mention that companies that have undergone this process in the past and primarily in Europe took a number of years to go through this process. We are trying to condense that to a shorter period of time, but it's not a exercise that one could go through in a couple of quarters. So we'll have more to say about it clearly next year, but you can be assured that we're working very hard on driving higher free cash flow ratio. And as we learn things along the way here with our analysis, we're making adjustments on an ongoing basis.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: So the first question I had is just on your spreads. Even if we exclude the variable investment income, spreads came down a lot. Especially in the Corporate Benefit Funding business, I think they're 150 -- 117 [ph] basis points versus almost 150 in the second quarter and the third quarter of last year. So what drove the decline? And is this a normal base that you're looking to grow off of? Or was there something abnormal in the second quarter that would have pressured your results beyond just the variable investment income impact?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is John. So yes, CBF spreads, you see looking at our quarterly financial supplement, do bounce around quarter-to-quarter. We had, in December '14 on our guidance call, said our spread outlook would be between 150 to 170 basis points, with 30 to 40 ba
componenttext: This is John. So yes, CBF spreads, you see looking at our quarterly financial supplement, do bounce around quarter-to-quarter. We had, in December '14 on our guidance call, said our spread outlook would be between 150 to 170 basis points, with 30 to 40 basis points from VII. If you're looking for the 9 months, we're at 173, with 39 from VII. But the third quarter was at the low end at 149, with 32 from VII. So you can see all this moves around quarter-to-quarter, a lot of VII second quarter. You remember we pointed out an accounting change that we did that also gave a boost to the second quarter of CBF. But we think this guidance still makes sense for the 150 to 170.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on the $900 million stat charge from foreign tax credits, I think you mentioned previously that the impact on your dividend capacity for 2016 would be around $90 million. Should we assume a commensurate impact in future periods as well beyond 201
componenttext: And then on the $900 million stat charge from foreign tax credits, I think you mentioned previously that the impact on your dividend capacity for 2016 would be around $90 million. Should we assume a commensurate impact in future periods as well beyond 2016?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. The -- well, this should be -- this is a onetime charge. Remember, statutory dividends are determined a year after the fact. The reason why it's not a larger impact is we're up against a lesser than rule of the New York, which is dividends are the les
componenttext: No. The -- well, this should be -- this is a onetime charge. Remember, statutory dividends are determined a year after the fact. The reason why it's not a larger impact is we're up against a lesser than rule of the New York, which is dividends are the lesser of 10% of surplus or your earnings in the year. So this did affect, as I said, our statutory earnings, but it did not affect the dividend capacity for next year because we're bumping up against the 10% number, the 10% limitation.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just lastly, on variable investment income, the weakness this quarter, I'm assuming it's hedge fund driven and maybe the other -- like the private equity and prepayments were somewhat normal, but maybe if you could give us some color on what dro
componenttext: Okay. And just lastly, on variable investment income, the weakness this quarter, I'm assuming it's hedge fund driven and maybe the other -- like the private equity and prepayments were somewhat normal, but maybe if you could give us some color on what drove the downside this quarter.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Steve Goulart. In looking at variable investment income for the quarter, most of the decline relative to plan in our range was in hedge funds. I mean, I think if you just look at what's happened in the market, hedge funds had a pretty weak quarter, a
componenttext: It's Steve Goulart. In looking at variable investment income for the quarter, most of the decline relative to plan in our range was in hedge funds. I mean, I think if you just look at what's happened in the market, hedge funds had a pretty weak quarter, and we saw it come through. I think John mentioned prepayments in some of his remarks. But prepayments were still in line with plan. They were just down from a high quarter on a year-over-year basis. So it's really all about hedge funds and VII. And as we look forward to the fourth quarter, we're comfortable that we'll be back in the range that we have set out, the $325 million to $425 million per quarter that we gave originally.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, happy to. Let me just look at that page. For our U.S. insurance companies, our statutory results were an operating loss of approximately $900 million and a net loss of approximately $700 million. And of course, this has -- the noncash tax charge was
componenttext: Yes, happy to. Let me just look at that page. For our U.S. insurance companies, our statutory results were an operating loss of approximately $900 million and a net loss of approximately $700 million. And of course, this has -- the noncash tax charge was $911 million on a statutory basis. $792 million went to statutory earnings and $119 million directly into surplus.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if we think about that $900 million loss, I mean, so you get $792 million of it from the charge. So then there's $108 million loss beyond that. I mean, is that -- so essentially, are all stat earnings being offset by the fact that you've underhedged on
componenttext: So if we think about that $900 million loss, I mean, so you get $792 million of it from the charge. So then there's $108 million loss beyond that. I mean, is that -- so essentially, are all stat earnings being offset by the fact that you've underhedged on the equity side?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that was one of the major impacts, and it was -- it's not underhedged. We don't fully hedge on smaller market moves, but we have a macro hedge that protects against larger market moves. So we're trying to be cost-efficient in how we do this. We're wi
componenttext: Yes, that was one of the major impacts, and it was -- it's not underhedged. We don't fully hedge on smaller market moves, but we have a macro hedge that protects against larger market moves. So we're trying to be cost-efficient in how we do this. We're willing to take some statutory volatility quarter-to-quarter to have an economical return on this product line, but we are well protected if larger shocks kick in.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question for Steve, I guess, is, in the press release, you talk about the ROE ex AOCI and other FCTA of 10.7%. And I know you don't give guidance on ROE. But as we think about kind of the trajectory of this, does it feel like the
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question for Steve, I guess, is, in the press release, you talk about the ROE ex AOCI and other FCTA of 10.7%. And I know you don't give guidance on ROE. But as we think about kind of the trajectory of this, does it feel like the ROE is sort of bottoming at this level? Or could we see some continued pressure that -- continued pressure on that ROE?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Suneet, obviously, the external pressures on us are significant, and we've discussed that. I'd say in the near term, given current interest rates and the macroeconomic factors, in that high 10%, 11% range is probably what we're looking at.
componenttext: Yes. Suneet, obviously, the external pressures on us are significant, and we've discussed that. I'd say in the near term, given current interest rates and the macroeconomic factors, in that high 10%, 11% range is probably what we're looking at.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Weiss from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I wanted to return to your comments regarding Fed regulation, specifically Tarullo's comments on nontraditional activities. I know earlier in the summer, you spoke about funding agreements, commercial paper, securities lending and guaranteed invest
componenttext: Steve, I wanted to return to your comments regarding Fed regulation, specifically Tarullo's comments on nontraditional activities. I know earlier in the summer, you spoke about funding agreements, commercial paper, securities lending and guaranteed investment contracts in terms of an area that the Fed may be looking closer at. If these were deemed nontraditional and were holding you up for the SIFI designation, how quickly would you be able to exit these businesses? And would you consider doing that if it would have a potential regulatory benefit?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Seth, those are shorter duration businesses and liabilities. So we could move pretty quickly. What we would do is once the capital rules came out, we would look at the costs and benefits to the company overall, and we'd have to make a decision based upon
componenttext: Seth, those are shorter duration businesses and liabilities. So we could move pretty quickly. What we would do is once the capital rules came out, we would look at the costs and benefits to the company overall, and we'd have to make a decision based upon that analysis. So until then, it's hard to say what we actually would do, but end of the day, it ended up being a fairly straightforward analysis for us.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And regarding variable annuities, do you have any hints if this something the Fed considers nontraditional similar to how the international regulators are looking at it? Or is this something that the Fed has perhaps shown some comfort around?
componenttext: Okay, great. And regarding variable annuities, do you have any hints if this something the Fed considers nontraditional similar to how the international regulators are looking at it? Or is this something that the Fed has perhaps shown some comfort around?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is John. The Fed has given no guidance as to what they're considering to be weighted in different ways. They're looking at all aspects of the insurance business, and the industry is in discussions with them. But they really have given us no indicatio
componenttext: This is John. The Fed has given no guidance as to what they're considering to be weighted in different ways. They're looking at all aspects of the insurance business, and the industry is in discussions with them. But they really have given us no indication at this time as to how they review any line of business.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jay Gelb from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jay Gelb from Barclays.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: With regard to the -- pushing out the long-term 10-year Treasury rate assumption to 11 years from 3 years, what are the implications on that for future margins? It seems like it would be less of a drag going forward.
componenttext: With regard to the -- pushing out the long-term 10-year Treasury rate assumption to 11 years from 3 years, what are the implications on that for future margins? It seems like it would be less of a drag going forward.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you say less of a drag, I mean, it's just the slope takes longer. We take a GAAP charge in that today, as you can see, and then it just -- the earnings flow-through over time. So I guess maybe I could follow up to clarify your question a little bit.
componenttext: When you say less of a drag, I mean, it's just the slope takes longer. We take a GAAP charge in that today, as you can see, and then it just -- the earnings flow-through over time. So I guess maybe I could follow up to clarify your question a little bit.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So it seems that if the assumption was previously, it was going to be 3 years to get there, and now we're talking 11 years, there might be less additions to reserves going forward. Is that -- am I thinking about that the right way?
componenttext: Sure. So it seems that if the assumption was previously, it was going to be 3 years to get there, and now we're talking 11 years, there might be less additions to reserves going forward. Is that -- am I thinking about that the right way?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it would be now set, I mean, if interest rates go up exactly according to the slope, then you just have normal profits coming through and no changes to DAC amortizations. This is primarily a DAC change. You have less profits in the future so you nee
componenttext: Well, it would be now set, I mean, if interest rates go up exactly according to the slope, then you just have normal profits coming through and no changes to DAC amortizations. This is primarily a DAC change. You have less profits in the future so you need to adjust your DAC today. And the patterns go out in a consistent manner.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the, I guess, the follow-up on the ROE comment. If I plug in 11% return on equity, I get to around $6 in earnings next year. That seems to be perhaps a little bit less than consensus was expecting. Any potential offsets to that, that we
componenttext: Okay. And then on the, I guess, the follow-up on the ROE comment. If I plug in 11% return on equity, I get to around $6 in earnings next year. That seems to be perhaps a little bit less than consensus was expecting. Any potential offsets to that, that we should be thinking about?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: Well, as -- I'd just like to remind you, we don't give forward guidance. We've given you our views, and I guess you can do the calculation, so thanks.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the higher P&C auto claims. It seems like you're experiencing the same issues some others in the industry are going through. Is this something that you'd expect to, I guess, recur for a period of time before you can -- rate increases p
componenttext: I had a question on the higher P&C auto claims. It seems like you're experiencing the same issues some others in the industry are going through. Is this something that you'd expect to, I guess, recur for a period of time before you can -- rate increases push through?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Eric. We probably are -- I think it's fair to say we're experiencing reasonably with the rest of the industry, as you've heard from other companies that they've been talking about more miles driven, as a result, higher accidents. You heard John say t
componenttext: It's Eric. We probably are -- I think it's fair to say we're experiencing reasonably with the rest of the industry, as you've heard from other companies that they've been talking about more miles driven, as a result, higher accidents. You heard John say that overall, our results frankly in both group and Retail is slightly higher frequency and severity. So we're not sure if this is going to continue for quarters and quarters and quarters. We are all over price increases. When we feel we have to take them as we have in this year, we will. And over time, we'll let you know what our decisions have been going forward. So right now, we don't see anything far out of line with what we've been expecting. But if we continue to see pressure, then you can be assured that we will take increases.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then for John, do you have any preliminary expectations for the impact of year-end statutory asset adequacy testing?

componenttext: Well, that would be done at the end of the year, depends on where interest rates end up and other factors. So I can't give you -- I can't predict where interest rates will be at the end of the year, and that's one of the most sensitive points.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Erik Bass from Citigroup.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the past, you've talked about a potential present value GAAP hit from sustained 2% rates is, I think, $3 billion. Are there any changes to that expectation? Or should we just think about the rate adjustment this quarter of approximately $180 million as
componenttext: In the past, you've talked about a potential present value GAAP hit from sustained 2% rates is, I think, $3 billion. Are there any changes to that expectation? Or should we just think about the rate adjustment this quarter of approximately $180 million as just subtracting from that amount?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is John. That would be correct, and we view the changes we made in this quarter were consistent within that overall guidance that we've given.
componenttext: This is John. That would be correct, and we view the changes we made in this quarter were consistent within that overall guidance that we've given.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on Japan, just one question. You mentioned the third sector sales being up 23% this quarter. Can you comment on the competitive trends in that market and how long of a sales cycle you see for the new products you've introduced?
componenttext: Okay. And then on Japan, just one question. You mentioned the third sector sales being up 23% this quarter. Can you comment on the competitive trends in that market and how long of a sales cycle you see for the new products you've introduced?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. It's Chris Townsend here. So we introduced some new products in the beginning of the fourth quarter last year. And as you can see, we've had pretty good growth right through the first 3 quarters of this year. So overall, third sector is up 23%.
componenttext: Yes, sure. It's Chris Townsend here. So we introduced some new products in the beginning of the fourth quarter last year. And as you can see, we've had pretty good growth right through the first 3 quarters of this year. So overall, third sector is up 23%. We've got a tough comparison coming up against the fourth quarter of 2014, but I think overall, the prior guidance we've given you in terms of sales at third sector was that we would grow it mid- to high single digits this year. Given the performance you've had so far, we can lift that guidance now to a full year out and move about 10% to 12%. So the new products are progressing really well. They give customers good choice, they are simple products, they've got segmented pricing, and all 4 of our key distribution channels are up. So we feel pretty good about that third sector right now.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Yaron Kinar from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Yaron Kinar from Deutsche Bank.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I actually want to follow up on Erik's question on the assumption review. So looking at this $3 billion in present value that you had talked about in the past from the low interest rate environment forever and comparing it to the $180 million we saw -- in
componenttext: I actually want to follow up on Erik's question on the assumption review. So looking at this $3 billion in present value that you had talked about in the past from the low interest rate environment forever and comparing it to the $180 million we saw -- in losses we saw this quarter, I was under the impression in the past that you had expected to see a lot of the charges coming in the first 3 to 5 years. And in that sense, I was a little surprised to see a relatively small impact from the new assumption this quarter and just wanted to square the 2.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think what we had said before when we gave this guidance about $3 billion, most of it is in DAC. And as you change your assumptions, that tends to be immediate, of course, on your DAC amortization. There's also a U.S. GAAP loss recognition testing that
componenttext: I think what we had said before when we gave this guidance about $3 billion, most of it is in DAC. And as you change your assumptions, that tends to be immediate, of course, on your DAC amortization. There's also a U.S. GAAP loss recognition testing that if you need to increase those, that's done over time. What I had said was I didn't expect to change assumptions immediately to go right down to flat 2% forever. It would take some time for us to ever to change our view on that as the world might change because for 10-year Treasuries to remain at 2% forever means that there's no inflation or -- and very little growth in the U.S. economy. We don't believe long term that, that is the case, but we now believe it will take a lot longer to get there from where we are today. So that's the assumption change. And as I said, the calculations we have done are consistent with the prior year guidance that I've given.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then turning back to P&C for a second, I was just wondering what was causing the more elevated or the greater deterioration, I guess, in group P&C versus Retail, bearing in mind the industry trends that we're seeing in frequency
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then turning back to P&C for a second, I was just wondering what was causing the more elevated or the greater deterioration, I guess, in group P&C versus Retail, bearing in mind the industry trends that we're seeing in frequency and severity?

componenttext: Yes. Are you talking about -- we didn't quite hear your question. Are you talking about the differential between group and Retail. That -- was that a part of your question?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right.
componenttext: Yes, that's right.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So buried in there is we had a little IBNR change, so that's why the subtlety of my previous answer might have been missed. But if you think about it -- if I were to normalize that IBNR change, I would say that the hit to group and Retail was roughly
componenttext: Yes. So buried in there is we had a little IBNR change, so that's why the subtlety of my previous answer might have been missed. But if you think about it -- if I were to normalize that IBNR change, I would say that the hit to group and Retail was roughly the same and completely driven by as I already said, miles driven, both frequency and severity in both businesses. So that's a little bit more of a normalized answer there.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Kovac from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Kovac from Goldman Sachs.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: With the equity market volatility, clearly, you saw the impact in the Annuities segment for you and your peers. I'm wondering if you can discuss some of the moving pieces, particularly around how managed volatility products and your hedge program performe
componenttext: With the equity market volatility, clearly, you saw the impact in the Annuities segment for you and your peers. I'm wondering if you can discuss some of the moving pieces, particularly around how managed volatility products and your hedge program performed in the third quarter versus both your expectations and maybe some other market downturns.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is John. The -- as I said, the separate accounts were down about 6%. Our managed vol funds actually did a little better than that, but we're still negative. They were just -- around 4.5%  was about the amount for the target vol funds. So target vols
componenttext: This is John. The -- as I said, the separate accounts were down about 6%. Our managed vol funds actually did a little better than that, but we're still negative. They were just -- around 4.5%  was about the amount for the target vol funds. So target vols are supposed to be better. But to react in a quick quarter like this, it's harder for these. So they did perform a bit better than what the S&P did, which is down about 7%. And our separate account returns in total were down about 6% but not flat or anything. It was a pretty rough quarter for the equity markets.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then as you think about variable annuity sales going forward, I know you had guided to 50% and then 20%, and this quarter came in about 15%. Any thoughts on the outlook?
componenttext: And then as you think about variable annuity sales going forward, I know you had guided to 50% and then 20%, and this quarter came in about 15%. Any thoughts on the outlook?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Eric. The number that I've been looking at, so you're quoting the pure variable annuity number, when I look at VAs and our shield product in the third quarter, we were up 26%, and that's quite a good result. Our shield sales continue to increase q
componenttext: This is Eric. The number that I've been looking at, so you're quoting the pure variable annuity number, when I look at VAs and our shield product in the third quarter, we were up 26%, and that's quite a good result. Our shield sales continue to increase quarter over -- quarter-after-quarter sequentially, and I think we're going to see the same thing generally in VAs. Certainly, as we moved from '14 -- frankly, from the '12 through '14 period of decreasing sales, '15 was that inflection point and honestly very hard to project. So we're below what we had thought we would be able to do. There's a number of reasons for that. This quarter, obviously, volatility in the equity markets. State approvals throughout the year play a big part. Certain key states came a fair amount later than we had thought they would. However, at this point, sales are looking pretty good. The Flex product continues to take hold both in our captive channel and in all of our independent channels. So I'm confident going forward that we'll see good sales results, certainly double-digit sales results.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Nadel from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Nadel from Piper Jaffray.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I -- a lot of questions asked and answered. You have a wide range for the loss expected for the corporate segment for the full year. I think if we make all of your normalizing adjustments, you're around a $420 million loss, but you have a range of, I beli
componenttext: I -- a lot of questions asked and answered. You have a wide range for the loss expected for the corporate segment for the full year. I think if we make all of your normalizing adjustments, you're around a $420 million loss, but you have a range of, I believe, it was $550 million to $750 million. Can you give us some help on one end of that range or where in that range you expect to end the year given this got just a few months left?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I still stick with that range. We have timing of preferred dividends now. We refinanced the -- one of our preferred dividends, and there's a gain this quarter because it's now a semiannual dividend, and it will hit the fourth quarter. So there's goin
componenttext: Yes. I still stick with that range. We have timing of preferred dividends now. We refinanced the -- one of our preferred dividends, and there's a gain this quarter because it's now a semiannual dividend, and it will hit the fourth quarter. So there's going to be some bumpy timing as we -- as you look quarter-to-quarter now. The old preferreds, so we took out where the quarterly dividend was smoother. The new piece that we did, it's a net savings to us by doing this, but it'll be more bumpy.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I wanted to think about the -- on a normalized basis, the Asia segment has seen a reasonable amount of volatility in earnings for a business that I think should generally -- versus more of your capital market sense of the bu
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I wanted to think about the -- on a normalized basis, the Asia segment has seen a reasonable amount of volatility in earnings for a business that I think should generally -- versus more of your capital market sense of the business is I would expect to be a bit more stable and predictable. That range is pretty wide on a quarterly basis, so I just -- thinking about second quarter and third quarter here in particular, which one of those normalized numbers do you think is a better true indication of the earnings power of that business that you annualized it?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it's Chris Townsend here. We gave some guidance previously in terms of the range. It was a low single to -- sorry, high single to low double-digit earnings growth on a constant rate basis for Asia. And we're still sticking with that in terms of the yea
componenttext: So it's Chris Townsend here. We gave some guidance previously in terms of the range. It was a low single to -- sorry, high single to low double-digit earnings growth on a constant rate basis for Asia. And we're still sticking with that in terms of the year for 2015. If you look at this quarter for instance, obviously, last quarter, we have that very high one-off tax issue in Japan, which threw the numbers out. But for this quarter, the constant rate growth is 26%, and there's 3 main items in that. One is business growth which accounts for about 11% or 12% of that. One is favorable investment income of $21 million, which is about 7%. And then there's a couple of one-off tax items. So you should probably think about $310 million to $320 million plus or minus 5% that that's sort of average run rate for the Asia business.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your final question today comes from the line of Eric Berg from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And your final question today comes from the line of Eric Berg from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick questions. The increase in the number of years that you expect to be 10 year to reach for, I think, in the quarter, from 3 to 11 strikes me as a major change. And so my question is, at least it strikes me that way. And so my question is,
componenttext: A couple of quick questions. The increase in the number of years that you expect to be 10 year to reach for, I think, in the quarter, from 3 to 11 strikes me as a major change. And so my question is, at least it strikes me that way. And so my question is, is this something that you have decided recently that you've been thinking about for a while? And given that interest rates have actually risen this year, treasury yields are flat, but credit spreads have widened, as you think about what has happened in the world, what has prompted you to make what seems to be such a dramatic change in your outlook for interest rates?

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. This is John. So obviously, where interest rates go long term is very important for us in how we price, how we think and how we account for our business. We've spent a lot of time thinking about, is 4.5% still the correct long long-term assu
componenttext: Thanks, Eric. This is John. So obviously, where interest rates go long term is very important for us in how we price, how we think and how we account for our business. We've spent a lot of time thinking about, is 4.5% still the correct long long-term assumption? And when I say long term, we're putting liabilities on the books today that may last for 100 years given life expectancies of young people. So it's a very long-term assumption. So that -- we think about that. And the question is, how fast will we get there? And I would say currently, and we would talk to a lot of economists and academics on this and look to the global economy, I think given this year compared to even a few years ago where there was much more optimism about the recovery of the world economies, we see a much slower growth for now and for the foreseeable future. And that's why we've put a longer slope going out on the treasury rate, which is the risk-free rate. When it comes to credit spreads, we really normalize those over the entire credit cycle. And the fact they're up in a quarter or down in a quarter doesn't really impact our thinking over a very long-term cycle. And we study credit spreads over decades, and that's how we set these long-term assumptions. And we're lucky we have experience of credit cycles over decades and have very good experience in this. So that's sort of our thinking behind how we set these assumptions.

headline: MetLife, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: And there are no further questions.
